The following statement is on the REST-* architectural goals page:

"Whenever possible, avoid envelope formats. Examples of envelope
formats are SOAP and Atom. Envelope formats encourage tunneling over
HTTP instead of leveraging HTTP. They also require additional
complexities on both the client and the server.

Is this elaborated on somewhere?  I don't think I've ever heard the
argument made before and  I'm not sure I get why an envelope format is
intrinsically good or bad in a protocol.  It seems orthogonal to
whether something is RESTful or not.


--Chuck
